questions.text: A 25-Year-old G2P1 with 37 weeks of gestation presents with the passage of a sudden gush of fluid 3 hrs ago. There is no history of pain abdomen or contractions. She is a known case of DM on treatment. Her first and second trimester usg is normal; previous lab investigations are within normal limits. On examination, P-90/min, BP-124/82mmHg, RR-13/min, temperature-99.5F, saturation normal. Abdominal examination shows vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. PV examination shows cervix not effaced, not dilated, membranes not felt. All of the following could be causes for this condition except –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High BMI The given clinical scenario points towards premature rupture of membranes. DEFINITION: Spontaneous rupture of the membranes any time beyond the 28th week of pregnancy but before the onset of labor is called premature rupture of the membranes (PROM). Low BMI( < 19kg/m²) is associated with PROM . Hence Option D) is the answer. Options A, B and C are the causes of PROM.

Highyeild:

Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) is defined as spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour. Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) is defined as premature rupture of membranes before 37 completed weeks.

Extraedge:

Chorioamnionitis is the predominant risk for patients with PROM between 32 and 36 weeks. Therefore the dominant tendency in their management should be toward delivery. Hyaline membrane disease is the predominant risk for patients with PROM between 28 and 32 weeks. Administration of glucocorticoids and prolonging the latent phase benefit these patients if they do not have clinical or subclinical chorioamnionitis.

questions.text: A 25-Year-old G3P1A1 with 36 weeks of gestation presents with a history of Continuous leak of fluid white to slightly yellow. There is no history of fever or pain abdomen. She has no comorbidities. On examination, P-88/min, BP-126/80mmHg, RR-13/min, temperature-99F, saturation normal. Abdominal examination shows fundus below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. PV examination shows cervix not dilated and not effaced, admits tip of the finger, membranes +. NST was normal. Litmus paper test and microscopic slide examination showed PROM. All of the following are maternal complications of this condition except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary hypoplasia The given clinical scenario is that of All the Options except Pulmonary hypoplasia are maternal complications seen in PROM. Pulmonary hypoplasia is a fetal complication of PROM. Maternal complications of PROM: Chorioamnionitis, placental abruption, retained placenta, endometritis, maternal sepsis and even death.

Highyeild:

DANGERS: The implications are less severe when the rupture occurs near term than earlier in pregnancy. Regarding PROM, labor starts in 80–90 Percent of cases within 24 hours. PROM is one of the essential causes of preterm labor and prematurity; The chance of ascending infection increases if labor fails to start within 24 hours. Liquor gets infected (chorioamnionitis), and fetal infection supervenes; Cord prolapse, mainly when associated with malpresentation; Continuous escape of liquor for a long duration may lead to dry labor; Placental abruption; Fetal pulmonary hypoplasia, especially in preterm PROM, is a real threat when associated with oligohydromnios; Neonatal sepsis, RDS, IVH and NEC in preterm PROM; Perinatal morbidities (cerebral palsy) are high.

questions.text: A 26-Year-old G2P1 with 35 weeks of gestation presents a history of fever with a Continuous leak of clear-coloured fluid. She has no comorbidities. Her previous lab investigations and usg are normal; she has had regular ANC. On examination, P-90/min, saturation normal, temperature-98.5F, RR-15/min, BP-110/82mmHg, pallor +, pedal edema+. Abdominal examination shows fundus below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. PV examination shows cervix not dilated and not effaced, admits tip of the finger, membranes +. Fetal NST was normal. Litmus paper test and microscopic slide examination confirmed PROM. Management of this patient includes-

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for 24-48hrs for spontaneous onset of labour

questions.correct_answer: C. Wait for 24-48hrs for spontaneous onset of labour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wait for 24-48hrs for spontaneous onset of labour The clinical case scenario points towards PROM . As the gestational age is 35 weeks and NST is normal no signs of fetal distress, waiting for 24-48 hours for spontaneous onset of labour is indicated.

Highyeild:

PROM - is defined as spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. PROM is not an indication for Cesarean section. Option: B & D. Induction of labour and delivery would be considered if signs of fetal distress or infection were present

Extraedge:

M/C etiology for PROM is infection (Chlamydia-trachomatis, group B streptococci and bacterial vaginosis) Patients present with a typical history of sudden gush of clear or pale yellow fluid leaking from the vagina. However, many women may present a history of intermittent or constant leaking of small amounts of fluid or a sensation of wetness within the vagina.

questions.text: A 26-Year-old primigravida with 35 weeks of gestation presents a history of increased micturation and fever for 2 days. She has no comorbidities. On examination, P-88/min, BP-128/88mmHg, RR-13/min, saturation 96 Percent, temperature-100F, pallor +. Abdominal examination shows fundus below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. PV shows cervix uneffaced, not dilated, admits, the tip of the finger, pelvis adequate, membranes absent. The confirmation of the case is by. Ferning pattern may be seen Amnisure By nitrazine paper Usg Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above The given clinical case scenario is that of premature rupture of membranes. Confirmation of diagnosis: Speculum examination is done taking aseptic precautions to inspect the liquor escaping out through the cervix; To examine the collected fluid from the posterior fornix (vaginal pool) for: Detection of pH by litmus or Nitrazine paper. The pH becomes 6–6.2 (Normal vaginal pH during pregnancy is 4.5–5.5, whereas that of liquor amnii is 7–7.5). Nitrazine paper turns from yellow to blue at pH > 6; To note the characteristic ferning pattern when a smeared slide is examined under a microscope; Centrifuged cells stained with 0.1 Percent Nile blue sulfate showing orange-blue coloration of the cells (exfoliated fat-containing cells from sebaceous glands of the fetus); AmniSure —A rapid immunoassay is accurate; Ultrasonography is to be done to support the diagnosis and assess fetal well-being. The digital vaginal examination should be avoided.

Highyeild:

Nitrazine test for Diagnosis of Premature rupture of Membranes: Principle: The vaginal pH is normally 4.5 to 5.5, whereas amniotic fluid usually has a pH of 7.0 to 7.5. Test: Nitrazine paper is smeared with vaginal secretions. Result: Nitrazine paper will turn deep blue if amniotic fluid is present in vagina i.e., membranes have ruptured as pH will become alkaline. The membranes probably are intact if the color of the paper remains yellow or changes to olive-yellow (pH 5.0 to 5.5). False result: Antiseptic solution, urine, blood, and vaginal infections alter the vaginal pH and cause false-positive results.

Extraedge:

Per speculum examination - The first step in diagnosing PROM includes "a sterile per speculum examination to demonstrate leaking. Pooling of fluid in the posterior fornix or leakage of fluid from the cervical os confirms the diagnosis of PROM. A per-vaginal examination should not be done as it increases the risk of intrauterine infection and preterm labour.

questions.text: A 35-Year-old G2P1L1 presents to the antenatal clinic at 35 weeks of pregnancy with C/O, leaking per vagina. The sample of pooled liquid turned red litmus paper blue, and ferning was present. The temperature of the patient is 102-F, and her pulse is 104. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer antibiotics The fluid in the vagina is amniotic, as shown in the fern pattern on microscopy (presence of sodium chloride in liquor). The red litmus turned blue (vaginal pH is acidic; amniotic fluid is alkaline). This patient with premature rupture of membranes (PROM) has a physical examination consistent with an intrauterine infection or chorioamnionitis. When chorioamnionitis is diagnosed, fetal and maternal morbidities increase and delivery is indicated regardless of the fetus's gestational age. In the case described, labor should be induced, and antibiotics to be given to avoid the neonatal group of streptococcal infection. Ampicillin is the drug of choice.

Highyeild:

Acute Chorioamniotis is diagnosed Clinically in the presence of a fever of 37.8 C) and at least two of the following Maternal tachycardia Fetal tachycardia Uterine tenderness Foul-smelling amniotic fluid me Maternal leucocytosis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. There is also no role for the administration of steroids as it is contraindicated in case of chorioamnionitis. Option B. There is no role for tocolysis in the setting of chorioamnionitis since delivery is the goal: Option D. Cervical cerclage is done in women with cervical incompetence . It is done during 2nd trimester.

questions.text: A female with 36 weeks gestation came to the clinic and was diagnosed with premature rupture of the membrane with a slow leak of blood from the vagina. what is the appropriate management to be done in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: To wait for spontaneous onset of labour for 24-48 hours and, if failed, induction of labour with oxytocin.

options.label: B
options.text: A couple of counselling to be done and then induction of labour

options.label: C
options.text: Bed Rest, Antenatal Corticosteroids, Broad Spectrum Antibiotics Given

options.label: D
options.text: Expectant management to be done immediately

questions.correct_answer: A. To wait for spontaneous onset of labour for 24-48 hours and, if failed, induction of labour with oxytocin.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To wait for spontaneous onset of labour for 24-48 hours and, if failed, induction of labour with oxytocin. PROM occurring at 36 weeks of gestation indicates waiting for spontaneous onset of labour for 24-48 hrs because there is a release of prostaglandins after rupturing of membranes which may cause labour induction. Still, if there is no spontaneous induction of labour, we can induce labour, with oxytocin because as membranes have already ruptured, there is increased chances of infection if pregnancy is continued.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option B. Couple counselling or reassurance may not be effective in PROM Option C. Antenatal steroids are indicated if PROM occurs at < 34 weeks Option D. Expectant management is Not effective . We have to do induction of labour.

Extraedge:

Diagnostic Therapeutic ● Ultrasound examination of cervical length ● Bed rest ● ELISA test for detecting Fetalfibronectin Protein in cervico vaginal secretion ● Avoidance of coital activity ● Progesterone injection (weekly)Or suppository (daily) till 35 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: A multi-gravida female presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes. which of the following antibiotics Is preferred for her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV Erythromycin According to RCOG guidelines. erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic for Preterm PROM with a dose of 250mg IV every 6 hours for 48 hours after that, 5OO mg per oral every 8 hours for 5 days. SPONTANEOUS RUPTURE OF MEMBRANES BEFORE THE ONSET OF LABOUR between 28-37 weeks is called preterm PROM . If preterm PROM occurs between 28-34 weeks, prophylactic antibiotics and corticosteroids are given to the patient. If PROM occurs after 34 weeks, we do induction of Labour and antibiotics. Its side effects are : G I upset Nausea Anorexia

Highyeild:

"Antibiotic prophylaxis is given to prevent preterm birth in pregnant women with preterm premature rupture of membranes (for pregnancies between 24 and 32 weeks) -Fenando Arias 3/e, p 252 One of the most important objectives of antibiotic treatment in women with PPROM is prolonging the latency period. Prolongation of the latency period is important because fetal lung maturity improves with advancing gestational age, resulting in fewer days in the ventilator and shorter stay at "-Fernando Arias 3/e, p 252

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Oral amoxicillin Is used In Decrial infections during pregnancy, commonly with a dose of 500 mg TDS. It Is safer during pregnancy. Option: B. IV AMPICILLIN is used in certain bacteria such as meningitis, throat Infections and sinuses and UTIs with a dose of 1.2 gm quarterly 4-6 hourly. Option: D. ORAL Doxycycline is not used during pregnancy as it can affect tooth and bone development in baby

Extraedge:

USE OF ANTIBIOTICS : Prophylactic antibiotics are given to minimise maternal and perinatal risks of infection. Intravenous ampicillin, amoxicillin or erythromycin for 48 hours, followed by oral therapy for 5 days or until delivery is recommended. Pelvic rest and antibiotics help to seal the leak spontaneously and reduce infection.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation complained of blood-tinged vaginal discharge. A nitrazine paper test was performed on her. What is this test used to detect?

options.label: B
options.text: Fetal blood cells in RH iso-immunization

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pre-Mature Rupture Of Membrane(PROM) The nitrazine paper test is used to detect PROM. It detects the pH of secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH > 6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 to 7.3, whereas the Normal pH of the vagina is less than 4.5. False positive nitrazine tests can be seen in contamination of discharge with blood. semen and bacterial infections.

Highyeild:

Nitrazine test for Diagnosis of Premature rupture of Membranes: Principle: The vaginal pH is normally 4.5 to 5.5, whereas amniotic fluid usually has a pH of 7.0 to 7.5. Test: Nitrazine paper is smeared with vaginal secretions. Result: Nitrazine paper will turn deep blue if amniotic fluid is present in vagina i.e., membranes have ruptured as pH will become alkaline. The membranes probably are intact if the color of the paper remains yellow or changes to olive-yellow (pH 5.0 to 5.5). False result: Antiseptic solution, urine, blood, and vaginal infections alter the vaginal pH and cause false-positive results.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. Fetal HB in vasa previa is detected by the apt test . It is an alkali denaturation test using a KOH reagent. It is used to detect the presence of fetal blood in the maternal circulation in cases of suspected fetal-maternal hemorrhage. it's a qualitative test Option B. Fetal blood cells in RH iso-immunization is an estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering maternal circulation in RH ISO immunisation is by kleihauer betke test, a quantitative test. It distinguishes between fetal and maternal blood cells based on the type of hemoglobin present. Option D. Abruptio placenta Is diagnosed mainly based on clinical features of abdominal discomfort followed by vaginal bleeding, which is continuous and dark-coloured . It is one form of APH in which bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta. it is mainly of 3 types, namely revealed. concealed and mixed. features of preeclampsia are absent.FHS is irregular.

Extraedge:

Confirmation of diagnosis: Speculum examination is done taking aseptic precautions to inspect the liquor escaping out through the cervix; To examine the collected fluid from the posterior fornix (vaginal pool) for: Detection of pH by litmus or Nitrazine paper. The pH becomes 6-6.2 (Normal vaginal pH during pregnancy is 4.5-5.5, whereas that of liquor amnii is 7-7.5). Nitrazine paper turns from yellow to blue at pH > 6; To note the characteristic ferning pattern when a smeared slide is examined under a microscope; (c) Centrifuged cells stained with 0.1% Nile blue sulfate showing orange, blue coloration of the cells (exfoliated fat-containing cells from sebaceous glands of the fetus); AmniSure-A rapid immunoassay is accurate; Ultrasonography is to be done to support the diagnosis and assess fetal well-being. A digital vaginal examination should be avoided.

questions.text: Which among these are the neonatal complications in the case of PROM?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Respiratory Distress Syndrome Rds (respiratory distress syndrome), nec ( necrotizing enterocolitis), sepsis, bpd (bronchopulmonary dysplasia), ivh( intraventricular hemorrhage) and pulmonary hypoplasia are some of the common neonatal complications of PROM.

Highyeild:

CAUSES OF PROM In the majority, the causes are not known. The possible causes are: Increased friability of the membranes; Decreased tensile strength of the membranes; Polyhydramnios; Cervical incompetence; Multiple pregnancies; Infection-Chorioamnionitis, urinary tract infection and lower genital tract infection; Cervical length <2.5 cm; Prior preterm labor and Low BMI (< 19 kg/m²).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. Fetal complications of PROM are infection and fetal distress due to umbilical cord compression. Option B. Maternal complications of prom Placental abruption, sepsis and maternal death. Option C. Chorioamnionitis, maternal complication

Extraedge:

DANGERS AND COMPLICATIONS OF PROM DANGERS: The implications are less severe when the rupture occurs near term than earlier in pregnancy. In terms of PROM, labor starts in 80-90% of cases within 24 hours. PROM is one of the essential causes of preterm labor and prematurity; The chance of ascending infection increases if labor fails to start within 24 hours. Liquor gets infected (chorioamnionitis), and fetal infection supervenes; Cord prolapse, mainly when associated with malpresentation; Continuous escape of liquor for a long duration may lead to dry labor; Placental abruption; Fetal pulmonary hypoplasia, especially in preterm PROM, is a real threat when associated with oligohydramnios; Neonatal sepsis, RDS, IVH and NEC in preterm PROM; Perinatal morbidities (cerebral palsy) are high. Maternal complications of PROM : Chorioamnionitis, placental abruption, retained placenta, endometritis, maternal sepsis and even death.
